A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.
Does the concept of a/an Integral Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Ring Isomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Ring Isomorphism involves a bijective ring homomorphism between two rings, R and R', where the mappings preserve the ring operations (addition and multiplication) and have inverses that also preserve these operations. This definition requires the structures involved to be rings, but it does not specify any additional properties that the rings must have beyond the basic ring axioms (associativity, commutativity of addition, distributivity of multiplication over addition, and the existence of additive identity and inverses).

An Integral Domain, on the other hand, is a specific type of ring. It is defined as a commutative ring with no nontrivial zero divisors and must be nonzero. This definition imposes additional conditions on the structure of the ring beyond those required for general rings.

Given that the definition of a Ring Isomorphism only requires the basic structure and properties of a ring, and does not require the absence of zero divisors or commutativity of multiplication (which are required in integral domains), the concept of an Integral Domain is not necessary for the definition of a Ring Isomorphism to make sense. The definition of Ring Isomorphism is applicable to any rings, not just integral domains.
